newsitem.title: HONG KONG: Shenzhen shares end up on technical rebound.
newsitem.headline: Shenzhen shares end up on technical rebound.

text.p: Shenzhen's A and B share indices ended higher due to a technical rebound on Friday after Thursday's plunges, but volatile trading is seen ahead, brokers said.
The foreign currency B share index rose 2.33 points or 1.55 percent to end at 153.19, but turnover fell to HK$99 million from HK$178 million in the previous session.
The domestic A share index rose 3.58 points or 0.85 percent to 425.72 on turnover of 7.0 billion yuan against Thursday's 8.3 billion yuan.
"The indices rose on bargain-hunting as short-term technical indicators showed stocks looked oversold after yesterday's sharp drops," an analyst at Shenzhen J&A Securities said.
"The markets have not bottomed out and strong downward pressure looms ahead," he said.
Brokers said the movement of the indices on Monday will depend on whether there are further announcements over the weekend by the government to cool down stock trading.
"It's very clear that Beijing is decisive on dampening share prices and investors will be bearish about the markets in the near future," an analyst at Central-South Securities said.

Beijing on Wednesday announced it would ban state enterprises and listed firms from speculative stock trading, in a move clearly aimed at curbing the inflow of "hot money" into the country's overheated stock markets, brokers have said.
The announcement sent share prices in Shenzhen and Shanghai into free fall on Thursday.

On the B share market, newcomer Nanjing Posts & Telecommunication 2468.SZ was the most actively traded with volume of 6.93 million shares, rising HK$0.20 or 4.81 percent to HK$4.36 due to institutional buying, brokers said.
Nanjing Posts, which issued 100 million B shares at HK$2.43 per share earlier this month, began trading on Thursday.
On the A share market, Shenzhen Development Bank rose 2.41 yuan or 6.58 percent to 39.05 yuan, the most heavily traded counter with 41 million shares changing hands.
Traders said investors happy with the bank's dividend plans, to be confirmed at a shareholders' meeting next Monday.
